section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Yy and Zz, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (feature).
Begin Story Time by asking, Which animals in the book have feathers?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Make predictions.
Display appropriate book-handling behaviors.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the letters Yyand Zz.
Read aloud Yellow Yaks and Zebra Zooms.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have?How do theyuse them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animal is in the book? What is special about that animal?
What animal can you pretend to be? What are your special features?
What features do you see on the animals? Can you sort them by their features?
What animal can you draw that has a special feature? What can you tell me about that feature?
What materials will you use to make an animal? Will your animal have feathers, fur, or scales?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word yarn? Try to make that sound.
What materials will you use to build an animal? How will you build it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What Am I? by Quinina Hoyos, illustrated by Donald Wu. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Working Memory Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (clue, goal).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to What Am I?
Read closely and use working memory to answer riddles.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make predictions.
Identify rhyming words.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use the Activity Cards to review with children words that rhyme.
Guide children to use their working memories to find a picture of a word that rhymes with the name of a toy animal.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have?How do theyuse them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Where have you seen this kind of animal before? Show the features it has.
Can you try to act like one of the animals in your book?
Can you show five animals that have feathers?
What do you remember about the camel from the book we read? Write or draw about that.
Which animal can you make with these materials? What features will you show?
Which animal begins with the letter z? Can you change the letter z into a zebra?
Can you build a special house for an animal from the book we read? What materials will work best?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What Am I? by Quinina Hoyos, illustrated by Donald Wu. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Brocreative/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build science background, engage children in a song, and introduce vocabulary (habitat).
Begin Story Time by revisiting What Am I? and asking the guiding question, What features help animals stay safe?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make predictions.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to use play clay to make a real or imaginary animal with a special feature to help keep it safe.
Label the animals.
Encourage children to talk about the animals they created.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have?How do theyuse them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the animals in your book stay safe in their habitats?
How can you hide yourself like an animal? Why does your animal need to hide?
How can you use leaves to show me how some animals use their colors to stay safe in their habitats?
How can you write or draw about an animal and its habitat?
Can you draw or create an animal that uses its colors to stay safe?
Which letters would you use to write your animal’s name?
How can you build a habitat for an animal? Which materials will work best? Why?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What Am I? by Quinina Hoyos, illustrated by Donald Wu. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Photos © Shutterstock: clay (Stephen Rees), index cards (LifetimeStock), school supplies (Aleksey Sagitov).
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Fantastic Feet

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss what children have learned and introduce vocabulary (foot, feet).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Fantastic Feet and What Am I?
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: What body parts do animals have? How do they use them?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Make inferences.
Identify rhyming words.
Independently write letters to make words or word parts.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Make connections between situations.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to identify pictures of animals and notice how many feet they have and other features.
Have children sort the animals by the number of feet they have.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have?How do theyuse them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Tell me how the animals in your book get around.
Can you pretend to walk with duck feet? With horse feet?
Can you put the feet in order, from smallest to largest?
Which animal from FantasticFeet is the slowest? Can you write about it?
Can you make the tracks of different animals and compare them?
Think of the sound you hear at the beginning of yak. Can you draw that letter?
Can you create a foot that looks like a foot from the chart? How could you make it stronger than when you started?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. What Am I? by Quinina Hoyos, illustrated by Donald Wu. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © An Nguyen/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and introduce vocabulary (powerful).
Begin Story Time by asking, “Which animal feature would you like to have if you could?”
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make predictions.
Display appropriate book-handling behaviors.
Independently write letters to make words or word parts.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “Which animal feature from the book do you think is the best?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What body parts do animals have?How do theyuse them?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is your favorite animal that we’ve read about? Why is it your favorite?
Pretend you are a chameleon who just discovered you can change colors! What do you do?
Can you use counters to create a pattern of spots for a jaguar?
Can you write a story about the bee we read about in our book?
Pretend that you are an insect who needs to hide. Can you draw the insect and use some of the materials to hide it?
What letters would you use to make up a new animal name? Why would you choose those?
Which blocks are most helpful for creating animals? Why do you think that is?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

Make inferences and predictions about text.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Recognize rhyming words.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole- /small-group writing activities.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplishgoals.

Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.

Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
